questions.title: Credit Migration Expected Return
questions.question: A bond has YTM of 1.0% and modified duration of 4.5. Using the transition matrix and expected spread changes, calculate the expected 1-year total return under credit migration.
questions.explanation:
Expected total return = YTM + Expected Price Return

You correctly calculated the expected price return of -0.14%, but forgot to add the YTM.

• Expected price return: -0.14%
• YTM: +1.00%
• Total return: 0.86%
keyFormulas: Expected Total Return = YTM + Σ(Probability × -Duration × Spread Change)
questions.yourMistake: Only calculated expected price return, forgot to add YTM

questions.title: ABS Credit Analysis Approaches
questions.question: A commercial ABS is collateralized by short-term loans to small US retailers. The loan pool is granular and homogeneous. Which credit analysis approach is most suitable?
questions.explanation:
Pool Characteristics → Approach:

• Small + Heterogeneous → Loan-by-loan
• Medium-term + Dynamic → Portfolio-based
• Short-term + Granular + Homogeneous → Statistics-based

The key triggers were 'short-term,' 'granular,' and 'homogeneous' — all pointing to statistics-based.
questions.yourMistake: Chose portfolio-based instead of statistics-based

questions.title: CDS Cheapest-to-Deliver
questions.question: Jackson holds $20M Bond X and bought $20M notional CDS protection. Upon default, Bond X trades at 40% and Bond Y trades at 35%. What are total proceeds?
questions.explanation:
• Bond X value: $20M × 40% = $8M
• CDS payoff uses cheapest-to-deliver (Bond Y at 35%)
• CDS payoff: $20M × (1 - 35%) = $20M × 65% = $13M
• Total: $8M + $13M = $21M

CTD = bond with LOWEST market value. Protection buyer benefits from delivering the cheapest bond.
keyFormulas: CDS Payoff = Notional × (1 - Recovery Rate of CTD)
questions.yourMistake: Forgot to use cheapest-to-deliver bond for CDS payoff calculation

questions.title: Rolling Down the Yield Curve
questions.question: Given Eng's expectation for unchanged spot rates, what is the first-year return on a 3-year zero-coupon bond if f(2,1) = 1.95% and the 1-year spot rate = 0.75%?
questions.explanation:
If spot curve is unchanged, the bond 'rolls down' to a shorter maturity. The return equals the forward rate for that period, not the spot rate.

3-year bond held for 1 year earns f(2,1) = 1.95%
keyFormulas: Rolling yield = forward rate for the period, not the current spot rate
questions.yourMistake: Used 1-year spot rate (0.75%) instead of forward rate

questions.title: Yield Curve Theories
questions.question: Client 1's restriction (buy only bonds ≤3 years and cannot deviate regardless of returns) is most consistent with which theory?
questions.explanation:
Theory comparison:

• Segmented Markets: Investors CANNOT/WILL NOT leave their maturity segment regardless of returns
• Preferred Habitat: Investors WILL leave for sufficient premium

Client is restricted and cannot deviate — that's segmented markets, not preferred habitat.
questions.yourMistake: Confused preferred habitat (will leave for premium) with segmented markets (cannot leave)

questions.title: Net Stable Funding Ratio
questions.question: Which change would INCREASE a bank's Net Stable Funding Ratio (NSFR)?
questions.explanation:
NSFR = Available Stable Funding / Required Stable Funding

• Numerator (Available): Capital, long-term debt, stable deposits
• Denominator (Required): Loans, illiquid assets

Increase in long-term debt → higher numerator → higher NSFR
Increase in loans → higher denominator → lower NSFR
keyFormulas: NSFR = Available Stable Funding / Required Stable Funding

questions.title: Current Rate Method Translation
questions.question: Salto's revenue was USD 120M and COGS was USD 65M. Average rate = 43.26, historical inventory rate = 42.81. What is translated gross profit using current rate method?
questions.explanation:
Under current rate method, BOTH revenue and COGS use the average rate:

Gross Profit = (120M - 65M) × 43.26 = 55M × 43.26 = 2,379

Method comparison:
• Current Rate: Revenue = Average, COGS = Average
• Temporal: Revenue = Average, COGS = Historical
keyFormulas: Current Rate: All IS items at average rate
Temporal: Monetary at current, non-monetary at historical
questions.yourMistake: Used temporal method logic (historical rate for COGS) when question specified current rate method

questions.title: Hyperinflation Translation IFRS
questions.question: Under IFRS, how should Celeste translate the hyperinflationary subsidiary's income statement?
questions.explanation:
IFRS Hyperinflation (Two-Step):
1. Restate for inflation (IAS 29)
2. Translate ALL items at current end-of-period rate

After restatement, everything — BS and IS — uses current rate, NOT average.
questions.yourMistake: Thought average rate applies to income statement under hyperinflation

questions.title: SBC Excess Tax Benefit
questions.question: What is the impact of excess tax benefit from stock-based compensation on tax expense when market price at vest exceeds grant price?
questions.explanation:
If market price at vest > grant price:
• Tax deduction > Book expense
• Excess tax benefit → Decreases tax expense

If market price at vest < grant price:
• Tax deduction < Book expense
• Tax shortfall → Increases tax expense

questions.title: DB Pension Expense US GAAP
questions.question: Under US GAAP, pension expense calculation uses which return on plan assets?
questions.explanation:
US GAAP Pension Expense:
Current Service Cost + Interest Cost - Expected Return + Amortizations

IFRS Pension Expense:
Service Cost + Net Interest (uses same discount rate for both)

Key difference: US GAAP uses management's expected return (can differ from discount rate), not actual return. Actual vs expected difference goes to OCI.
keyFormulas: US GAAP: Service + Interest - Expected Return ± Amortizations
IFRS: Service + Net Interest
questions.yourMistake: Used actual return instead of expected return

questions.title: Full vs Partial Goodwill
questions.question: Apex (US GAAP) acquires 80% of Beast for $24M. FV of Beast's net assets = $25M, FV of entire Beast = $30M. How much goodwill?
questions.explanation:
Standard requirements:
• US GAAP: Full goodwill only
• IFRS: Choice of full or partial

Full Goodwill: $30M - $25M = $5M
Partial Goodwill: $24M - (80% × $25M) = $4M ← Not allowed under US GAAP
keyFormulas: Full Goodwill = FV of entire entity - FV of net assets
Partial Goodwill = Purchase price - % acquired × FV net assets
questions.yourMistake: Calculated partial goodwill ($4M) but US GAAP requires full goodwill

questions.title: Forward vs Trailing P/E
questions.question: If a stock's forward P/E is lower than its trailing P/E, what does this indicate about expected earnings?

choices.text: Earnings are expected to remain stable

questions.explanation:
• Forward P/E < Trailing P/E → Earnings are RISING
• Forward P/E > Trailing P/E → Earnings are FALLING

Logic: Forward uses next year's (higher) expected earnings in denominator → lower ratio.

questions.title: Residual Income Persistence
questions.question: Relative to industry, what does a low persistence factor (ω approaching 0) indicate?
questions.explanation:
Lower persistence (ω → 0) caused by:
• High dividend payout
• EXTREME levels of ROE (not low)
• HIGH accounting accruals

Higher persistence (ω → 1) caused by:
• Low dividend payout
• Normal/moderate ROE
• Low accruals
questions.yourMistake: Confused persistence factors - thought low persistence meant lower returns

questions.title: Finite-Horizon Residual Income
questions.question: When calculating intrinsic value using finite-horizon RI model, what discount rate should be used for the terminal premium?
questions.explanation:
V₀ = B₀ + Σ PV(RI) + (P_T - B_T)/(1+r)^T

• Use cost of equity, NOT WACC
• Terminal premium = Market price - Book value at horizon
• Discount at cost of equity because RI is an equity valuation model
keyFormulas: V₀ = B₀ + Σ PV(RI) + Terminal Premium/(1+r)^T
questions.yourMistake: Used WACC to discount terminal premium instead of cost of equity

questions.title: Two-Stage FCFE Valuation
questions.question: When using FCFE model for equity valuation, what discount rate should be used?
questions.explanation:
FCFE models discount at cost of equity (NOT WACC):

• FCFE = cash flow to equity holders → discount at cost of equity
• FCFF = cash flow to all capital providers → discount at WACC

Terminal Value calculated at END of high growth period, then discount back to today.
keyFormulas: FCFE → Cost of Equity
FCFF → WACC

questions.title: Putable Bond Binomial Valuation
questions.question: When valuing an American put option using a binomial model, at each node you should:

choices.text: Compare continuation value to exercise value and use the higher

questions.explanation:
At each node, compare:
• Continuation value (PV of expected future values)
• Exercise value (X - S for put)

If exercise value > continuation value → exercise early

Example: At T=1 when S = $80:
• Continuation value = $13.33
• Exercise value = $98 - $80 = $18
• $18 > $13.33 → Exercise!
questions.yourMistake: Calculated European put value instead of American (didn't check for early exercise)

questions.title: Covered Interest Rate Parity
questions.question: Calculate 6-month forward USD/NZD rate. Spot = 0.6808, US 6-month rate = 0.50% annual, NZ 6-month rate = 1.00% annual.
questions.explanation:
F = S × (1 + r_price × days/360) / (1 + r_base × days/360)

For 6-month forward, divide annual rates by 2:
F = 0.6808 × (1 + 0.0025) / (1 + 0.005) = 0.6791
keyFormulas: F = S × (1 + r_price × t) / (1 + r_base × t)
questions.yourMistake: Used annual rates without adjusting for 6-month period

questions.title: Forward Contract Value at Time t
questions.question: When valuing a forward contract with 3 months remaining on an original 9-month contract, you should discount for:
questions.explanation:
V_t = S_t - F₀/(1+r)^(T-t)

Use TIME REMAINING (T-t), not time elapsed.
If 3 months remain on 9-month forward, discount for 0.25 years.
keyFormulas: V_t = S_t - F₀/(1+r)^(T-t)
T-t = time remaining
questions.yourMistake: Used wrong time period for discounting

questions.title: Incremental VaR
questions.question: Which type of VaR measures the change in portfolio VaR from changing a position size?
questions.explanation:
VaR Types:

• Incremental VaR: Change in VaR from changing position size
• Marginal VaR: Per-unit change in VaR for small position change
• Component VaR: Contribution of a position to total portfolio VaR
• Conditional VaR: Expected loss given that loss exceeds VaR

questions.title: Information Coefficient and Active Weights
questions.question: Which combination would result in smaller optimal active weights?

choices.text: Decrease in both IC and target active risk
Increase in IC and decrease in target active risk
Increase in both IC and target active risk
Decrease in IC and increase in target active risk

questions.explanation:
Effect on Optimal Active Weights:

• Higher IC → Smaller weights (more confident forecasts need less extreme bets)
• Higher target active risk → Larger weights
• Lower target active risk → Smaller weights

Both higher IC AND lower target active risk → smallest weights
questions.yourMistake: Thought decrease in IC would reduce weights, but higher IC actually reduces optimal weights

questions.title: Transfer Coefficient
questions.question: What is the effect of portfolio guidelines restricting maximum over/underweights?
questions.explanation:
• Breadth = number of independent decisions (not affected by weight limits)
• Transfer coefficient = how well forecasts translate into actual portfolio weights

Constraints on weights reduce your ability to implement forecasts → lower TC.
questions.yourMistake: Thought constraints reduced breadth, but they reduce transfer coefficient

questions.title: Neoclassical Steady-State Growth
questions.question: Calculate steady-state growth rate. TFP growth = 2.1%, labor share = 55.2%, labor force growth = 0.9%.
questions.explanation:
ΔY/Y = θ/(1-α) + n

Calculation:
2.1% / 0.552 + 0.9% = 3.8% + 0.9% = 4.7%

Common mistakes:
• Adding directly (θ + n = 3.0%) ❌
• Dividing by capital share ❌
• Forgetting to add labor force growth (= 3.8%) ❌
keyFormulas: Steady-state growth = θ/(1-α) + n
where θ = TFP growth, α = capital share, n = labor growth
questions.yourMistake: Divided by capital share instead of labor share

questions.title: Currency Crisis Warning Signs
questions.question: Which condition is most likely a warning sign of currency crisis?

choices.text: Slight decline in foreign equity investment
Sizable decline in FX reserves relative to daily turnover

questions.explanation:
Warning Signs:
• Declining FX reserves ✓
• Large capital INFLOWS (not outflows) preceding crisis
• RISING M2/bank reserves ratio

NOT Warning Signs:
• Slight decline in foreign equity investment
• Declining M2/reserves ratio
questions.yourMistake: Confused declining M2/reserves ratio (not a warning) with rising ratio (warning sign)

questions.title: Cointegration Testing
questions.question: For two time series to be cointegrated, which null hypotheses must be rejected? H1: Series 1 has unit root. H2: Series 2 has unit root. H3: Residuals have unit root.

choices.text: Reject H1 and H2, fail to reject H3
Fail to reject H1 and H2, reject H3

questions.explanation:
Cointegration Requirements:
1. FAIL to reject H1: Series 1 has unit root (it does have one)
2. FAIL to reject H2: Series 2 has unit root (it does have one)
3. REJECT H3: Residuals have unit root (residuals ARE stationary)

Both series non-stationary + their combination is stationary = cointegrated
questions.yourMistake: Thought all three should be rejected, but only H3 (residuals) should be rejected

questions.title: ARCH Testing
questions.question: In testing for ARCH effects, you regress squared residuals on lagged squared residuals. If the coefficient is statistically significant, what does this indicate?
questions.explanation:
ARCH Test:
Regress squared residuals on lagged squared residuals:
ε²_t = a₀ + a₁ε²_{t-1} + u_t

If a₁ is significant → model has ARCH (conditional heteroskedasticity)

Note: Regression of regular residuals tests serial correlation, which is different.
keyFormulas: ARCH test: ε²_t = a₀ + a₁ε²_{t-1}
questions.yourMistake: Confused ARCH test (squared residuals) with serial correlation test (regular residuals)

questions.title: Mutual Information Feature Selection
questions.question: For text classification, which tokens should be selected as features?
questions.explanation:
Feature Selection:

• High TF: Remove — noise/stop words
• High DF: Remove — appears everywhere, no discriminating power
• High MI: KEEP — discriminates between classes

MI measures how much a token contributes to classifying text. High MI = token appears mostly in one class.
questions.yourMistake: Chose document frequency instead of mutual information

questions.title: Commodity Futures Total Return
questions.question: Total return on a commodity futures position includes which components?

choices.text: Price return + roll return + collateral return

questions.explanation:
Total Return = Price Return + Roll Return + Collateral Return

• Price Return: Change in spot price
• Roll Return: Gain/loss from rolling = (Near - Far) / Near
• Collateral Return: Interest on margin = Rf × (period/12)

Roll return is positive in backwardation (near > far), negative in contango.
keyFormulas: Total Return = Price + Roll + Collateral
Roll Return = (Near - Far) / Near

questions.title: Terminated Accounts Disclosure
questions.question: What must be disclosed when including terminated accounts in composite performance?
questions.explanation:
Terminated accounts MAY be included in composite performance, but firm MUST disclose the termination dates.

Omitting dates = violation even if returns are included.

questions.title: Fair Dealing / IPO Allocation
questions.question: How should IPO shares be allocated across accounts?
questions.explanation:
Allocate pro-rata to ALL suitable accounts:
• Discretionary accounts ✓
• Non-discretionary accounts ✓
• Family accounts ✓
• Non-family accounts ✓

Excluding non-discretionary or family accounts = violation of Standard III(B) Fair Dealing.
questions.yourMistake: Thought certain account types could be excluded

questions.title: Priority of Transactions
questions.question: Denton buys Bio13 in his personal account immediately. His client Hunter asked to delay purchase for 30 days. Did Denton violate Standard VI(B)?
questions.explanation:
Standard VI(B) Priority of Transactions requires client trades have priority over personal trades. However:

• Hunter explicitly requested the delay
• Denton's purchase caused only temporary price impact
• Hunter was not disadvantaged — 30 days later, price determined by market factors

No front-running occurred because the client voluntarily delayed.
questions.yourMistake: Thought any personal purchase before client = violation, but client explicitly requested delay

questions.title: Target Payout Adjustment Model
questions.question: In the target payout adjustment model, the adjustment factor equals:
questions.explanation:
Expected Div Increase = (Expected EPS × Target Payout - Previous Div) × Adjustment Factor

Adjustment Factor = 1 / Number of years to adjust

Calculate year by year iteratively.
keyFormulas: ΔDiv = (EPS × Target Payout - Prev Div) × (1/n)

questions.title: Currency Swap Fixed Rate
questions.question: The fixed rate on a currency swap at initiation is calculated as:

choices.text: (1 - PV of final payment) / Sum of all PV factors
Sum of all PV factors / (1 - PV of final payment)

questions.explanation:
Fixed Rate = (1 - PV_final) / Σ(PV factors)

Use PV factor for FINAL payment date in numerator.
Annualize by multiplying by payment frequency.
keyFormulas: Fixed Rate = (1 - PV_final) / Σ(PV factors)
